item.title: Brief introduction to AI/ML
item.dc:creator: Alberto Alvarez
item.description:
What is Machine Learning?

In today‚Äôs world, hearing about Artificial Intelligence (AI) in a daily conversation is not uncommon. We hear about it everywhere and everyone wants to talk about it, even if they have no real clue of how it works or what it really is. Some even say it will take over humanity very soon üëÄ.

There is another field that is unlikely to hear in daily conversations, but which is very tightly related to AI: Machine Learning (ML). There are many different definitions of what machine learning is, but let‚Äôs look at the following one to keep it simple:

‚ÄúField of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed‚Äù - Arthur Samuel (1959).

That is a very informal definition. Briefly, machine learning is the process in which a computer learns how to do a task or how to solve a problem. The rules have not been explicitly programmed by the human, instead found by the machine during its training process.

Types of Machine Learning

There are three main types of ML, which we briefly explain below:

  • Supervised learning: the machine learns from a given dataset that contains the right answers, thus the name ‚Äòsupervised‚Äô.
  • Unsupervised learning: The machine doesn‚Äôt know anything about the expected output, but tries to learn/find patterns in the data that can be later used to solve a task. Some example algorithms are:
    • Clustering
    • Anomaly Detection
    • Dimensionality reduction
  • Reinforcement learning: The machine learns by trial and error. Good examples for this are games, that a computer learns how to play by trial and error until it becomes very good at it.

Regression vs classification

Also, is important to differenciate a regression model from a classification model:

  • Regression model: Predicts values, such as house prices or temperature. These values are numbers like $250,000.00, 23.7 ¬∞C, etc. Infinitely many possible outputs.

  • Classification model: predicts classes or categories, such as a picture representing a ‚Äúcat‚Äù or a ‚Äúdog‚Äù. Discrete or finite set of possible outputs.

Terminology

  • Training dataset: Data used to train the model, i.e., fed to the algorithm for it to learn the rules to predict the outputs.
  • Validation dataset: Used to validate the trained model and evaluate the accuracy of prediction. It helps determine if the model is good at predicting outputs from unseen data. If not, more training is required, or a bigger training data.
  • Test dataset: Data used to test the model after trained and validated, to confirm real accuracy of model.
DeepLearning.AI - Machine Learning Specialization

Sometimes validation dataset and test dataset are used as one.

Do you already know a learning algorithm?

Linear regression

I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve heard before about linear regression, a very simple algorithm that fits a straight line to a given data. This algorithm belongs to supervised learning, since it uses available data to fit the line, which then can be used to predict a value (even though not very accurate). Mathematically, this algorithm is as simple as below:

where is the input value (feature) and is the prediction (estimation). and are scalar numbers that once computed, will fit the line to the given dataset.

So yes, if you took any basic math course, you know at least one learning algorithm, and it is very simple! Of course, this might not be very useful at very complex problems üòÖ.

Example

We have the prices for two houses: a small one (900 sqft) and a big one (1,450 sqft). The small one costs $150,000.00 and the big one $280,000.00. We would like to predict the price of a medium size house (1,050 sqft).

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x_train = [900, 1450]
y_train = [150000, 280000]

# Ignore for now how w and b are computed
w = 236.4
b = -62727

def predict(x):
  return w*x + b

# We want to predict the price of a house with 1,050 sqft size
medium_house = 1050
print('Predicted house price: {}'.format(predict(medium_house)))

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
plt.title("Housing Prices")
plt.xlabel("Size (sqft)")
plt.ylabel("Price (USD)")
plt.plot(x_train, y_train, linestyle = 'dotted', c='m')
plt.scatter(x_train, y_train, marker='o', c='b', label='Known prices')
plt.scatter(medium_house, predict(medium_house), marker='x', c='g', label='Predicted price')
plt.legend()
plt.show()
Predicted house price: 185493.0

The predicted price of medium size house is USD.

Conclusions

We learned some very basic, but useful, terminology of ML. We also looked at an example of a learning algorithm used to predict house prices based on size.

item.title: Getting back to it, starting from the basics of ML!
item.dc:creator: Alberto Alvarez
item.description:
First of all, welcome to my new personal blog, where I will share with you very interesting topics about AI/ML, programming and embedded systems üòÑ.

Where am I at the end of 2024?

Back in 2021 I took Andrew Ng‚Äôs ‚ÄúMachine Learning by Stanford University‚Äù specialization in Coursera, which was my first formal introduction to the amazing field of Machine Learning (ML).

It honestly felt really good to finish the specialization and not quit in the process. I must say, it was not easy! I remember some lectures were very complex, specially when learning about stochastic gradient descent (SGD) for the first time.

Anyways, I managed to finish the specialization and graduate from my Master‚Äôs, which eventually got me a job related to ML üéâ. I‚Äôm happy because of that!

I can proudly say that below certificate is my first one in the field! I‚Äôm sure it will not be the last one!

Since late 2021 I have worked in ML related tasks. I optimize and deploy deep learning models to embedded devices that have a deep learning accelerator or Neural Processing Unit (NPU).

Now I‚Äôm really interested in diving deeper into Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), Natural Language Processing (NLP), computer vision, optimization methods for Edge AI/ML and much more! To achieve that, I want to get back to the basics of ML to refresh the concepts and strengthen my skills, to eventually become an expert in the field.

I have decided to start my learning path again by taking the new, refreshed ‚ÄúMachine Learning Specialization‚Äù course from DeepLearning.AI and share with you my journey in this blog. I hope you like it!

DeepLearning.AI - Machine Learning Specialization

You can find the specialization at: Machine Learning Specialization.

Conclusion

I‚Äôm starting my AI/ML learning path from scratch again and I will document part of it in this blog. Come join me in this adventure! Looking forward to it! üíªüíØ
